block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Disgruntled Arafat Starts Diplomatic Tour Yasir Arafat left his base in the Gaza Strip on a diplomatic tour aimed at solidifying international support in the wake of the Camp David talks. As he departed for Paris, he gave vent to some of the frustration that has built up since the talks broke up over the issue of Jerusalem.

Prosecution Threatened in Peru President Alberto K. Fujimori blamed his political opponents for rioting on Friday that left six people dead, and his prime minister warned that organizers of the protests could be prosecuted.

Venezuela to Hold Elections Venezuela, two months after a first attempt collapsed, will try again today to hold the biggest vote in its history, an election in which thousands of candidates, from President Hugo Chavez down to state legislators, are competing.

Sect Leader Seeks Asylum Zhang Hongbao, a founder of an outlawed meditation-exercise sect in China who has spent months in hiding, has resurfaced in Guam, where he is seeking political asylum, according to the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. Chinese authorities want him returned.
(AP)

Heart Pioneer Found Dead Rene G. Favaloro, an Argentine cardiologist who developed revolutionary heart-bypass techniques at the Cleveland Clinic in the 1960's, was found dead of a gunshot wound at his home in Buenos Aires. The police said it was apparently a suicide. Dr. Favaloro was 77.
(Reuters)
NATIONAL

Bush Plans Wide Appeal In His Convention Speech Gov. George W. Bush said that in his speech to the Republican National Convention he would go out of his way to direct his appeal to the widest possible audience, including Democrats and independents.
The Republican Party has collected a record $137.4 million in soft money. But a central purpose of the party's convention is to motivate supporters to raise and give still more.
After two days of marathon sessions, the Republican platform reflects Gov. George W. Bush's stance on education, but stands firm on other issues.
Vice President Al Gore plans to announce his choice of a running mate on Aug. 8, a week before the Democratic convention in Los Angeles.
Doctor Program Lacks Money A federal program meant to attract health workers to remote towns and inner-city neighborhoods has exhausted its funds.
Slaves' Records Amassed The identities of more than 100,000 Louisiana slaves are emerging from centuries of anonymity now that their records have been assembled in a computer database.
Gun Program Defended The Clinton administration will continue paying local governments to buy back guns from private owners despite opposition in the House.
Protecting the Blue Crab A vast portion of the lower Chesapeake Bay has been declared a sanctuary to provide safe passage for the embattled blue crab.
NEW YORK/REGION

Neighbors Baffled by Actions Of J.F.K. Hijacking Suspect Residents of a northeast Milkwaukee red-brick apartment building say they have been in disbelief since a neighbor, Aaron Amartei Commey, was accused of boarding a National Airlines flight at Kennedy International Airport with a 10-millimeter handgun and a knife and holding the pilots hostage during a five-hour standoff.

Courting the Jewish Vote Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton are courting the Jewish vote with expressions of support for Israel and sniping at each other over who said what about relocating the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

A Lawyer's Call to Action The removal of Rezulin, a diabetes drug, and the restrictions on Propulsid, a medication for severe heartburn, served as a call to action for lawyers who specialize in large-scale litigation.
